captions.text:
Avowed, as well as being the sound people make 
if you punch them while they&#39;re telling you their

favorite James Cameron franchise, is—oh, can it 
be true, games industry? An actual original IP

with some decent financial backing? &quot;That&#39;s 
right, Yahtzee, but only if IP now stands

for &#39;Integrated into Pillars of Eternity.&#39;&quot; 
Because Avowed is by Obsidian Entertainment

and is set in the same universe as Pillars of 
Eternity, which is their generic fantasy &quot;we

want to make Baldur&#39;s Gate but don&#39;t have the 
rights to Baldur&#39;s Gate anymore&quot; franchise,

and I don&#39;t have much experience with it &#39;cause 
isometric RPGs don&#39;t usually click for me,

ironically; I put that down to my morbid 
phobia of floor textures. Avowed, thankfully,

is a first-person action RPG, so if it ever 
gets too much, I can calm myself down with a

nice ceiling. That&#39;s first-person action Western 
RPG as opposed to JRPG; if you need a refresher

on the difference, JRPGs are about teenagers 
using the power of friendship to kill God;

WRPGs are about grown-ups with unresolved 
traumatic backstories using the power of difficult

moral choices to kill God. Or become God. Or 
talk God into shooting themselves in the head.

So we start Avowed, and predictably enough, we 
open with a pretty standard character creator,

except after you&#39;ve chosen your skin tone, build, 
and hairdo, the game goes, &quot;Right, now pick what

hideous, nightmarish mutation you want growing out 
of your fucking face.&quot; Er... could I just not have

one of those, Avowed? &quot;I guess, but every NPC is 
going to be talking at you like you&#39;ve got one and

visibly holding back dry heaves, so you might as 
well pick something.&quot; Alright, I&#39;ll just go with

a really unflattering moustache. We have to pick 
a horrible face disaster because we are a Godlike,

you see, a person with a direct line to a 
God that gives us special powers, and the

ruler of the fantasy British Empire has called 
upon us to go to a distant, untamed land where

a mysterious madness-inducing disease is fucking 
up efforts to establish a colony and basically go

British Empire all over the place. And we&#39;re 
the one best qualified for this task because

the disease gives its victims fucked up faces, 
and the emperor figured we&#39;d get along. Then,

our ship gets wrecked on the way to the island, 
and we wake up on a beach, which is the standard

RPG practice, isn&#39;t it? That&#39;s just the next 
step after choosing stat perks and penis length.

&quot;Standard&quot; certainly is the word. The open-world 
RPG that follows is as bog standard as it gets;

you go through a series of enclosed maps with 
the obvious terrain themes—grasslands, forest,

desert, lava world—go to the one town or part 
of each map that isn&#39;t infested with spiders,

bears, and skeletons and go around it hoovering up 
side quests that all revolve around clearing other

parts of the map of spiders, bears, and skeletons. 
I hear some of my peers have been down on Avowed,

which I assume is because, given its heritage, 
they were expecting something more sophisticated.

Something systems driven along Baldur&#39;s Gate 
or Kingdom Come: Deliverance lines. That&#39;s

not what Avowed is. You should expect a bit of an 
action RPG rather than a bit of RPG action. Avowed

doesn&#39;t do systems for shit. There&#39;s no crime 
or reputation mechanic. You can barge straight

into an NPC&#39;s house, shouldering past them in 
the doorway, fill your pockets with the entire

contents of their cutlery drawer, and no one will 
bat a fucking eye. You can&#39;t fight friendlies, no

day-night cycles, no NPC schedules, ranged weapons 
all have infinite ammo, and on the whole, the game

makes no bones about the fact that the main thing 
you will be doing is combat. &quot;Ooh, can I roll a

stealth character with high charisma for talking 
around problems?&quot; No, you fucking can&#39;t. Here&#39;s

a selection of long, heavy things. Choose one, 
hold it by the stubby end, and very insistently

introduce the other end to everything you see 
like it&#39;s an unmarried daughter in her 30s.

There is a stealth attack, but it&#39;s not a 
guaranteed kill, and enemies are always in groups,

so you&#39;ll be lucky to take down more than 
one of the dozy fuckers before the entire

Monster United Nations show up and motion 
to strongly condemn. All in all, as RPGs go,

it&#39;s a very stripped-down one. There&#39;s a 
grand total of four party members, none of

whom are up for snogging and aren&#39;t interesting 
enough characters to get me in the mood for it,

anyway. They all just sort of invite themselves 
into the party at regular intervals in the plot.

Which is your favorite, the facetious one, 
the very facetious one, the not facetious one,

or the very not facetious one? The story generally 
isn&#39;t much to write home about, unless your

parents are particularly interested in generic 
fantasy plots because their doctor told them

to keep their heart rates down. One of the main 
villains looks like Skeletor, for fuck&#39;s sake.

So if you take the inevitable option to side with 
them, then I don&#39;t know what to tell you, frankly,

except that you probably didn&#39;t put enough points 
into your paying attention stat. I do like the

range of dialogue options the protagonist is 
given; you can be humble, you can throw your

weight around as the emperor&#39;s envoy, you can be 
a surly asshole who tells everyone to piss off.

There&#39;s also a ton of unique dialogue for 
what background you picked, which is nice,

but none of it changes anything, really. 
There&#39;s not much in the way of speech checks,

unless you count making sure not to click on 
the option that says, &quot;Actually, I&#39;ve decided

you smell weird [Attack].&quot; So there&#39;s no escaping 
having to do a lot of the aforementioned sticking

the knobbly end of things into unending supplies 
of monsters. But you know what? Fucking good.

Expectations for open world RPGs have been set too 
high these days. I don&#39;t fucking care if a quest

giver moves from their designated standing spot 
to go brush their teeth twice a day, realistic

or immersive though that might be; I care that I 
can fucking find them when I&#39;m ready to hand in

the 17 pairs of soiled kobold sanitary pads they 
asked for. &quot;Do anything actions have consequences

real living world&quot; bullshit is overrated, there is 
virtue in keeping focused on one thing, and Avowed

isn&#39;t trying to be anything but a combat game. 
Yes, following quest markers in ascending order of

projected difficulty to fight repetitive clusters 
of gormless tits like a massively overinvolved

join-the-dots puzzle can feel a bit World of 
Warcraft-y at times, but it&#39;s a pretty world to

explore with lots of fun discoveries to be made. 
And most importantly, whether you&#39;re blatting a

lizard man with a mace hard enough to make him 
turn somersaults or using a bolt-action rifle to

blow the jaw off a skeleton who was told this was 
gonna be a melee fight, lol, the combat is fun.

And that is the factor that made me keep playing 
Avowed and keep looking forward to each session.

I didn&#39;t mind the obligation to keep crafting 
weapon upgrades &#39;cause it was fun to feel the

difference in power when a weapon got up to 
Exceptional rather than Shithouse quality. I

didn&#39;t mind that your party members are useless in 
fights &#39;cause the lack of classes or obligation to

specialize means you can pretty much one-man-band 
it with a mace in one hand, pistol in the other,

and magic wand Sellotaped to your inner thigh. 
Towards the end of the game, a quest rewarded me

with a magic mace that restored my health 
whenever I swung it, and not by a crumb,

like a third of the health bar at a time; I can&#39;t 
imagine this will escape a nerf in future updates

unless the intention was to make all the endgame 
combat about as challenging as picking the pubes

out of my teeth, but I was still having fun. In an 
era where the Soulslike genre continues to rub up

against the tropic of fuckabout, it&#39;s refreshing 
for a game to let me be overpowered and tear up

its insides like a medieval childbirth assistance 
device. I mean, we are supposed to be the avatar

of God, why not let us go full-on Jesus versus 
the moneylenders? While there&#39;s other stuff I

could complain about in Avowed—I hate that 
I can only upgrade my stuff while at camp,

so if I was just shy of resources, I have to break 
camp, gather what I need, then immediately camp

again, risking my party members worrying I&#39;ve got 
narcolepsy—but at the end of the day, you can&#39;t

argue with a strong primary gameplay loop. Well, 
you can. You could say, &quot;Fuck you, strong primary

gameplay loop. Stop reminding me of the trauma 
I suffered while learning to tie my shoelaces.&quot;
